p: We used the Maximum Entropy modeling method (Phillips, Anderson, & Schapire, 2006) implemented in the software MaxEnt version 3.3.1 (Phillips, Dudik, & Schapire, 2004), to develop niche models of habitat suitability for each Xenosaurus species. MaxEnt is a maximum entropy‐based program that estimates the probability distributions of a species in a geographic space using occurrence records and environmental data (Phillips et al., 2006). This modeling algorithm only requires presence data and has relatively good performance when compared to other presence‐only methods (Elith et al., 2006). To establish the areas that maintain the environmental conditions of the species and that could be occupied by them (Burgman & Fox, 2003; Elith et al., 2011), MaxEnt generates habitat suitability maps scaling from zero (low suitability) to 1 (high suitability; Elith et al., 2011). Data of the seven bioclimatic variables used for the study were collected for the whole background using the software ArcMap version 10.3.
